entry.title: Interfacing SD with MCU: Part 3
entry.content:
Data on storage media is organized using a filesystem. A computer’s operating system can access the contents of storage media via the filesystem. In this project, we will use the Fat Allocation Table (FAT) to format our SD Card. You can find additional information on the FAT file system.

To access the contents on the Secure Digital Card (SDC) with the FAT file system on a microcontroller (MCU), we need to use an external C library called FATFs. This library abstracts low-level commands for handling SDC transactions. However, for a small 8-bit MCU like the Atmega16, we can use Petit FATFs, which is a variant of FATFs with a smaller code footprint and fewer functionalities.

As we learned in tutorial 1, the MCU and SDC fundamentally communicate using the SPI protocol. The SDC has an internal MCU that communicates with the Atmega16. The functioning of Petit FATFs can be organized into a three-level hierarchy, as shown in Fig 1:

  1. The lower level is MCU-dependent and handles SPI transactions.
  2. The middle level handles disk I/O functions following the MMC/SD standard protocol.
  3. The highest layer provides the application interface for Petit FATFs.

Fig 1. Petit FATFs Usage

1) Low-Level Functionality

This level handles SPI initialization and SPI read/write byte operations. To understand how SPI works on the Atmega16, refer to the datasheet. The SPI clock frequency needs to be set according to the requirements. You can find a template file for Atmega16, and assembly code implementations to handle SPI in PetitFAT sample projects in the resource section.

2) Middle Level

This level handles disk I/O functionality and abstracts MMC/SD commands. Specifically, it initializes the SDC and provides an API for card sector modification. More information on MMC/SDC usage can be found on the project website. The SPI command set provides a set of available commands, while a specific SPI response is received by the MCU upon issuing an SPI command to the SDC. These responses are useful in the debugging process and can be monitored using an LCD module.

To debug card initialization, you can check the ocr variable value using an LCD screen after getting a command response in the disk_initialize function. You can find the disk I/O functions in mmc.c (or avr_mmcp.c) and its configuration in diskio.h.

3) High-Level Functionality

This layer uses the disk I/O layer API to provide the Petit FATFs API for the application interface. You can find the functions in pff.c and definitions in pff.h. It is possible to customize API functions as per requirements using the file pffconf.h. Include these three files in your main.c and use the API application interface for handling file management on the SD Card.

This completes the three-part tutorial on interfacing and handling an SD Card for MCUs like Atmega16. It is advised to use an SDC with a storage capacity of less than 2 GB for initial testing. Hope you find it useful!

entry.title: Interfacing SD with MCU: Part 2
entry.content:
In this part of the tutorial, we will explore how to wire an SD Card with an ATMEGA16. The SD Card requires a 3.3 V supply, so we will first create a circuit for this purpose. You can use voltage regulators like the LM117 (fixed 3.3 V output) or a variable one like the popular LM317. There is no need for a heatsink for these ICs in this application as the power dissipation is quite small. I prefer using the LM317 (TO-223 package); it can be easily soldered, is readily available, and the circuit requires only a few supplementary passive components. Proceed with the following circuit.

Tested with R2 = 360 Ohms and R1 = 240 Ohms.

If you get an output voltage within about 200 millivolts of 3.3 V, it’s perfect! Otherwise, try adjusting the resistor values slightly until you achieve the desired voltage. We have now constructed a power supply for the SD Card. The next step is to build a logic converter circuit to interface the AVR with the SD Card. While it’s not always necessary to have an interface circuit, it becomes essential if the AVR operates at a voltage other than 3.3 V. When not working at the same voltage, the SD Card requires a logic level converter to translate its 3.3 V signal to the AVR and vice versa. There are a couple of methods to build one, but we will use the voltage divider method, which is simple and works in most cases. However, you can explore other methods like the pull resistor method or find a ready-made IC for this purpose.

Voltage Divider Method:

With Vs as the primary supply voltage to the system, the calculation of R2 and R1 is pretty simple:

R2 = Vs * (R1 + R2) / (2 * 3.3 V - Vs)

Now, let’s say your microcontroller is working on 5 V; then, the ratio R2 comes out to be twice that of R1:

R2 = 2 * R1

You can try different values for R2 and R1, within the range of 1 KOhm to 50 KOhm. I successfully tested this circuit with R2 = 2.2 KOhm and R1 = 1.1 KOhm.

Once you’ve done that, power the SD Card with the 3.3 V power supply we created using the LM317. You can even design both circuits (supply and logic converter) on the same board, which simplifies the setup.

Usually, we don’t find 9-pin MMC cards in the market nowadays as they have become obsolete. However, there are various microSD cards available, which are compatible with cellphones, mp3 players, and other similar devices. So, you can comfortably use such a microSD card with an adapter (the black one) to serve your purpose. This adapter requires another card socket, which requires careful soldering. Also, its SMD soldering pads are very fine and delicate.

MicroSD with Adapter

SD Card Adapter Socket

Here’s a alternative method if you don’t want to deal with SMD connectors. It can save you time, effort, and frustration. Solder a 9 X 1 male berg strip to the pinouts of the adapter, as shown in the figure below. Solder a 9 X 1 female berg strip on your interface circuit as your pinout. This method allows for easy plug-in and removal of the adapter without damaging it.

entry.title: Interfacing SD with MCU: Part 1
entry.content:
This is the first part of a tutorial series that will guide you in using an SD Card for your AVR ATMEGA projects. A Secure Digital Card (SDC) is a versatile and compact storage peripheral widely used for file storage due to its small size and compatibility with nearly all digital devices. Its application can be extended to overcome data storage limits in embedded systems. In this tutorial, we will demonstrate how to interface an SD Card with an AVR family microcontroller. We will use the popular ATMEGA 16 for demonstration, but the method can be extended to any 8-bit MCU. As a prerequisite, I strongly recommend refreshing your C programming skills and going through the datasheet of ATMEGA16, especially the SPI part.

Let’s begin with a quick review of the basics of an SD card. An SDC is an upgraded standard of the Multimedia Card (MMC) with improved compatibility with numerous digital devices and significantly higher storage capacity. It contains an array of flash memory and an inbuilt microcontroller to handle data requests. SDC supports two protocols: SD and SPI (Serial Peripheral Interface). We will use the SPI protocol as it is easy and provides a speed of about 100 KHz-500 KHz, which is sufficient for various applications on ATMEGA16.

While older versions of Multimedia Cards (MMC) are no longer in fashion, recent SD Cards follow the same pin connections for SPI. microSD cards are widely used today due to their convenient design, which suits most digital devices and can be easily adapted for an SD interface using a suitable adapter. Since we will be using SPI mode, we only need to be concerned about four SPI and two power supply pins, regardless of the type of card used.

SPI Mode

Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) enables synchronous communication between two devices supporting this protocol with efficient speed. ATMEGA16 (acting as the master) communicates with the microcontroller in the SDC (acting as the slave) using the SPI protocol. This mode is characterized by the following pins (refer to the ATMEGA16 datasheet):

  • Master In Slave Out (MISO): Data transferred from slave to master device.
  • Master Out Slave In (MOSI): Data transferred from master to slave device.
  • CS (Chip Select): Active Low chip selection of the slave by the master.
  • SCLK (Clock Line): Clock Line provided by the master to the slave for maintaining synchronization between the two.

SDC operates on 3.3V logic and requires the same supply voltage. While ATMEGA16 can operate on 3.3V, in many applications, it is powered by a 5V DC supply. Therefore, there is a need for logic conversion circuitry between the two peripherals. Several methods are available for building such a circuit; you can search the internet for more details. However, I suggest using a simple resistor network circuit, as it has been practically tested.
